etymology.description: 女(女) (nǚ, "woman") + 又(又) (yòu, "hand") = a hand capturing and ordering a woman -> servant
etymology.interpretation: This character combines 女(女) (nǚ, "woman") with 又(又) (yòu, "hand") to symbolize a hand exerting control over a woman, indicating subjugation or servitude. It captures a historical view of societal roles.

examples.chinese: 他被迫成为奴(他被迫成為奴)。
examples.english: He was forced to become a servant.

examples.chinese: 这个奴全心全意侍奉主人(這個奴全心全意侍奉主人)，从不怨言(從不怨言)。
examples.pinyin: Zhège nú quánxīn quányì shìfèng zhǔrén, cóng bù yuànyán.
examples.english: This servant serves his master wholeheartedly and never complains.

examples.chinese: 昔日名将的奴曾立下汗马功劳(昔日名將的奴曾立下汗馬功勞)。
examples.pinyin: Xīrì míngjiāng de nú céng lìxià hànmǎ gōngláo.
examples.english: The servant of the once-famous general once accomplished remarkable feats.
